quotes.topic_title: Marketplace gardening metaphor and treading lightly
quotes.text: One lesson I learned the hard way a bunch of times on this is that if you think about running a marketplace, you're basically like a gardener.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model for marketplace operators that emphasizes nurturing an ecosystem rather than building linearly.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace gardening metaphor and treading lightly
quotes.text: You have to have a very light touch.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Actionable guidance that marketplace changes should be minimal and carefully applied to avoid unintended consequences.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace gardening metaphor and treading lightly
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS business, you're a construction worker, you're building the product and the features and selling it, and it's this very linear thing.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Contrasts SaaS and marketplaces to clarify why marketplace growth requires different tactics and expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace gardening metaphor and treading lightly
quotes.text: For a marketplace, you're like messing with this ecosystem that you don't actually really understand how it works.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Highlights the inherent complexity and partial observability of marketplaces, warning against overconfidence in interventions.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace gardening metaphor and treading lightly
quotes.text: So I think that the main advice is like to tread lightly. When you're messing with the core incentives or mechanisms of a marketplace, be very careful, particularly if you've got something that's working on playing with those variables.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Direct, practitioner-ready advice to avoid destabilizing a functioning marketplace by tweaking core incentives without extreme caution.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I interview world class product leaders and growth experts to learn from their hard won experiences building and scaling today's most successful companies.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Sets a practitioner-oriented learning model: extracting repeatable lessons from people who have scaled real companies.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This episode gets very deep into the weeds and so, if you're working on a growth strategy or you're building a marketplace business, this episode is for you.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A clear targeting heuristic: the content is designed for people actively doing growth strategy or marketplace building (not casual listeners).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We've always thought of Amplitude as being about supporting the full product loop, think collect data, inform [inaudible 00:02:08] ship experiments and learn.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A concise growth methodology framing: growth as a closed-loop system from data → decisions → experiments → learning.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: about a third of people will consider switching to another company after just one bad experience during onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: A concrete retention/conversion data point highlighting how fragile onboarding is and why fixing it can be high leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I don't think I learned much about how to actually run a business at those places, but I did learn a lot about how to think about them.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career insight: some roles teach mental models more than operational execution—useful when choosing learning environments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, we've always thought of Amplitude as being about supporting the full product loop, think collect data, inform [inaudible 00:02:08] ship experiments and learn. That's the heart of growth to us.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Offers a practical growth framework (“full product loop”) that teams can use to structure analytics, experimentation, and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So the big aha was seen how many customers were using Amplitude to analyze experiments, use segments for outreach and send data to other destinations. Experiment and CDP came out of listening to and observing our customers.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Highlights a product expansion method: follow emergent customer behavior and build what they’re already hacking together.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, based on our data, about a third of people will consider switching to another company after just one bad experience during onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: A concrete retention risk data point that quantifies how costly onboarding failures can be.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I've consistently seen that improving onboarding is one of the highest leverage opportunities for both signup conversion and increasing long-term retention. Getting people to your aha moment more quickly and reliably is so incredibly important.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization advice: treat onboarding speed/reliability to the “aha moment” as a top growth lever.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's incredible to see how our customers like Square, Spotify and Zuora are able to grow their businesses on top of flat file, this because flawless data onboarding acts like a catalyst to get them and their customers where they need to go faster.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: Uses recognizable examples and a “catalyst” mental model to frame data onboarding as a growth accelerant.

quotes.topic_title: What a growth model is and why
quotes.text: And that's how I think about a growth model, so the analytical representation of how the business grows and it's typically built in a spreadsheet which has a really nice feature of being very hard to fake.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Defines a growth model as a concrete analytical artifact (often a spreadsheet) that enforces rigor because it’s difficult to hand-wave assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: What a growth model is and why
quotes.text: You can talk about a business conceptually, but when you actually have to get it to line up and link in a model, it's very hard to not force yourself to understand how the business works.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Highlights the practical benefit: modeling forces clarity about causal links and mechanics of growth.

quotes.topic_title: What a growth model is and why
quotes.text: I think 50% of the value you get from it is simply building the model.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic that reframes the model as valuable primarily for the learning created during construction.

quotes.topic_title: What a growth model is and why
quotes.text: I think importantly it is not a forecasting tool, so it's not going to replace what your finance team is building to project the business.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Counterintuitive positioning: the growth model is for understanding and decision support, not precise prediction.

quotes.topic_title: What a growth model is and why
quotes.text: but it is a great tool for kind of opportunity assessment for the business.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Clarifies the primary use case: comparing initiatives and estimating upside under different assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: How to build growth models by business type
quotes.text: So actually if you're modeling a relatively simple SaaS business, those are the only core building blocks you need and you add a lot more complexity on it based on your kind of individual business that you're building.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A practical baseline framework for SaaS modeling: start with acquisition, retention, monetization, then add only business-specific complexity.

quotes.topic_title: How to build growth models by business type
quotes.text: But where it gets really interesting is we start making it non-linear. So the most basic example of this would be virality. Your existing customers are referring new customers and those go on to refer new customers. Based on that coefficient, it has a lot to do with how fast your business grows.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Highlights the key shift from linear spreadsheets to compounding dynamics (virality) that can dominate growth outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: How to build growth models by business type
quotes.text: as you generate contribution margin, you can reinvest that and grow and actually if you link those two up explicitly, it makes it really clear why thinking about something like payback period is a much better measure of paid marketing performance than LTV to CAC because the speed at which you get enough money back to then go acquire another customer has much more bearing on how fast your business can grow than just the raw kind of [inaudible 00:09:39].
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A contrarian metric recommendation: payback period can matter more than LTV:CAC because reinvestment speed drives growth rate.

quotes.topic_title: How to build growth models by business type
quotes.text: As soon as you start stacking assumptions, you're highly sensitive to how many assumptions do you have to make and do you know how to make that assumption.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A warning about model fragility: compounding assumptions can make outputs unreliable unless each assumption is well-grounded.

quotes.topic_title: How to build growth models by business type
quotes.text: So the thing that I have gravitated to more as I've done more of this is one very basic high level conceptual model, so that's like the building blocks you talked about, which as simply as possible describes how the whole system works. And so you start to get a feel for which levers are important.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Recommends a methodology: use a simple top-level model to identify key levers before building deeper, more detailed sub-models.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace modeling pitfalls and mini-model approach
quotes.text: As soon as you start stacking assumptions, you're highly sensitive to how many assumptions do you have to make and do you know how to make that assumption.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A warning that marketplace models become fragile quickly as assumptions compound, making outputs overly sensitive and unreliable.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace modeling pitfalls and mini-model approach
quotes.text: But how much of that was actually incremental?
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Highlights the core modeling pitfall in marketplaces: separating true incremental growth from demand that would have happened anyway.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace modeling pitfalls and mini-model approach
quotes.text: And so if you're not careful, you can have a junk in, junk out problem with marketplaces.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that uncertain marketplace assumptions can make sophisticated models misleading rather than helpful.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace modeling pitfalls and mini-model approach
quotes.text: So the thing that I have gravitated to more as I've done more of this is one very basic high level conceptual model, so that's like the building blocks you talked about, which as simply as possible describes how the whole system works.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A practical modeling methodology: start with a simple system-level model to identify the most important levers.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace modeling pitfalls and mini-model approach
quotes.text: And then for each area of the business, so each product pod, each go to market team, they should have their own kind of mini model which describes the piece of the business they're working on.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A scalable operating framework: decentralize modeling into team-level mini-models tied to each pod’s scope and metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Templates, Reforge, and retention as key lever
quotes.text: We probably built 20 or 30 these in my time at Basis One.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A concrete data point establishing Dan’s volume of experience building growth models and lending credibility to the advice that follows.

quotes.topic_title: Templates, Reforge, and retention as key lever
quotes.text: One thing I'll say is going back to 50% of the value being figuring it out, that actually negates the value of templates in some way.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take that templates can reduce learning, implying teams should build models themselves to truly understand the business.

quotes.topic_title: Templates, Reforge, and retention as key lever
quotes.text: So the more painful the process of building it is, probably the more you're learning.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for practitioners: difficulty in model-building is a signal of deeper understanding being gained.

quotes.topic_title: Templates, Reforge, and retention as key lever
quotes.text: One of the immediate things that you see when you build these is that your growth is much more sensitive to customer retention than you can ever intuit because there's a lot of interaction between having a healthy retained customer base and everything else you care about, which is the rate at which they're referring new customers, generating content, generating contribution margin.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A systems view of growth: retention amplifies multiple downstream growth drivers (referrals, content, margin), making it a primary lever.

quotes.topic_title: Templates, Reforge, and retention as key lever
quotes.text: I think one tactical piece of advice, I think the best way to start this is to find a smart analyst or smart finance person often is the right type of person to partner with and just start building it.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Practical guidance on how to operationalize growth modeling: partner with analytical talent and iterate by building rather than debating.

quotes.topic_title: Using growth models for planning and allocation
quotes.text: The most difficult thing about making that kind of effort is developing a common currency by which you can trade off their efforts.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Highlights the core planning challenge: comparing disparate team initiatives requires a shared unit of impact.

quotes.topic_title: Using growth models for planning and allocation
quotes.text: The growth model is the function that lets you do that.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Defines the growth model’s job as the mechanism that makes cross-team tradeoffs comparable.

quotes.topic_title: Using growth models for planning and allocation
quotes.text: So now we have a spreadsheet that says these are the things we could work on. This is roughly how it will impact our short or long-term growth. Now you have the ability to make much better kind of allocation decisions.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Gives a practical methodology for scenario-planning initiatives and allocating resources based on modeled impact.

quotes.topic_title: Using growth models for planning and allocation
quotes.text: If you look at the strategy doc for a product group or team, I think that having a model like this should be a core part of that because that way they can articulate what it is they actually [inaudible 00:19:18].
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Recommends embedding a growth model directly into team strategy docs to clarify which levers drive the north star.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack example: shifting resources beyond top funnel
quotes.text: it made it so immediately obvious that we were exceptionally sensitive to the repeat rate of new customers.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Shows how building a growth model can reveal the single variable (repeat rate) that disproportionately drives outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack example: shifting resources beyond top funnel
quotes.text: the rate at which we did that made all the difference because it radically changed the LTV of that customer, which then fed back into how much we could go pay to acquire new customers.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Connects cross-sell/repeat usage directly to LTV and paid acquisition capacity—an actionable loop for marketplace growth strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack example: shifting resources beyond top funnel
quotes.text: We shipped hundreds of experiments to increase our conversion rate. We had done much less on the life cycle piece like how do we cross sell you into these other things.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A concrete example of over-investing in top-of-funnel optimization while under-investing in lifecycle/cross-sell levers.

quotes.topic_title: Thumbtack example: shifting resources beyond top funnel
quotes.text: Building this model helped us internalize that we needed to shift a bunch of resources from top of funnel to deeper in the stack and that ultimately let us build a much better customer journey.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Actionable takeaway: use modeling to justify reallocating growth resources toward deeper lifecycle improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Improving retention: early experience and reducing variability
quotes.text: Retention is a tough measure to work on because it is the culmination of the entire product experience.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Frames retention as an outcome metric driven by end-to-end experience, not a single tactic, guiding teams to look upstream.

quotes.topic_title: Improving retention: early experience and reducing variability
quotes.text: And so I think that the primary advice is actually if you were trying to remove a retention style metric, rarely should you go right to the source and send them more email or push notification or something like that.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance to avoid “nudges” as the default retention lever and instead fix underlying experience issues.

quotes.topic_title: Improving retention: early experience and reducing variability
quotes.text: Very often I think the biggest wins in retention come from inflecting the early user experience.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization: focus retention work on onboarding/first-use moments where beliefs and habits are formed.

quotes.topic_title: Improving retention: early experience and reducing variability
quotes.text: So if you can target streamlining that experience or homogenizing that experience, it's typically very helpful.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Introduces a practical lens—reducing early experience variability—to prevent “bad luck” from causing churn.

quotes.topic_title: Improving retention: early experience and reducing variability
quotes.text: This is why you see both of those companies dueling it out to guarantee the highest first first week or first month earning.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Concrete marketplace example (Uber/Lyft) of using early guarantees to pull up worst initial outcomes and improve retention curves.

quotes.topic_title: Why marketplaces are compelling and hard
quotes.text: They're very hard to get started, super capital intensive to get started, but once they're rolling, they're very hard to stop. You get this kind of compounding defensibility and gains that makes them very hard to stop.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A concise mental model for marketplace venture dynamics: high upfront difficulty and cost, followed by compounding defensibility once liquidity takes hold.

quotes.topic_title: Why marketplaces are compelling and hard
quotes.text: So typically, as you acquire more and more customers, you're acquiring the marginally good fit customer over time and your CACs go up, your LTVs go down, it gets harder and harder.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Establishes the baseline expectation for most businesses, useful as a contrast when diagnosing whether a marketplace is behaving “normally” or not.

quotes.topic_title: Why marketplaces are compelling and hard
quotes.text: Marketplace is actually the inverse. The supply liquidity is improving, the experience is improving. So often actually as you see later cohorts in marketplaces, CAC goes down, LTV goes up. You see this crazy inversion where the business gets better and better over time.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A counterintuitive, practitioner-relevant metric pattern to look for in healthy marketplaces: later cohorts can get cheaper to acquire and more valuable.

quotes.topic_title: Why marketplaces are compelling and hard
quotes.text: I think everything is just harder. Every question is more complex
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A warning and expectation-setter for operators: marketplace problems tend to involve second-order effects and higher complexity than single-sided products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern growth team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical gap teams should plan for: experimentation is critical, but tooling may not fit modern stacks out of the box.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to waste of time building internal tools or trying to run your experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Calls out a common operational failure mode that slows growth teams—either reinventing tooling internally or forcing experiments into the wrong system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved about our experimentation platform was being able to easily slice results by device, by country, and by user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete methodology for experiment analysis: segment results across key dimensions to uncover heterogeneous effects.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click through metrics and instead use your north star metrics like activation, retention, subscriptions and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Reinforces an actionable measurement principle: optimize experiments against north-star outcomes rather than shallow proxy metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And Eppo supports tests on the front end, the back end, email marketing and even machine learning clients.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Expands the experimentation surface area beyond UI changes, encouraging practitioners to test across the full product and delivery stack.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace health metrics: GMV, unit economics, liquidity, share
quotes.text: You need something that brings together both the supply and demand side to make sure it's working and that's typically your ultimate north star of which everything else ladders up to.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Frames GMV/transactions as the unifying top-line metric that integrates both sides of a marketplace.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace health metrics: GMV, unit economics, liquidity, share
quotes.text: Instacart famously was losing the money on every order. Uber was losing money on every drive.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Concrete examples that normalize negative early unit economics in marketplaces and motivate tracking the drivers behind them.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace health metrics: GMV, unit economics, liquidity, share
quotes.text: And so by articulating what the customer cares about and where this threshold is, you can tell when you have a liquid marketplace and essentially until you have a liquid marketplace, really nothing else matters.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Defines liquidity as a reliability threshold tied to user experience and elevates it as the gating metric for marketplace success.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace health metrics: GMV, unit economics, liquidity, share
quotes.text: If you could tell me we could grow GMV 10% by getting 10% more customers or by getting 10% more of our current customers' wallet, I would take the latter because you now have a deeper relationship with them, which tells you something more about the future retention and defensibility of the marketplace.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Counterintuitive prioritization of depth (share of wallet) over breadth (new customers) as a driver of defensibility.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace health metrics: GMV, unit economics, liquidity, share
quotes.text: So I think it's basically a measure of depth rather than breadth. And I will take depth every time in a marketplace.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Memorable rule-of-thumb for choosing growth strategies that strengthen retention and reduce multi-tenant behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Supply vs demand focus and ROI equations
quotes.text: However, I think this tricks people into thinking that that's the optimization function or you think you should think more about supply. I think ultimately demand is the only thing that matters. If you are successful at aggregating the demand in your industry, you will have the winning marketplace.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Contrarian reminder that demand aggregation—not supply growth—is the true long-run marketplace moat and north star.

quotes.topic_title: Supply vs demand focus and ROI equations
quotes.text: And the culmination of those two points is you only should acquire supply to the extent you understand how it impacts demand.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Actionable rule for prioritization: invest in supply only when it measurably improves the demand-side experience.

quotes.topic_title: Supply vs demand focus and ROI equations
quotes.text: But actually the thing that matters is can you write an ROI equation for acquiring supply and demand which fully internalizes the marketplace dynamic.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A practical framework for deciding constraints: use ROI/payback models that account for cross-side acquisition dependencies.

quotes.topic_title: Supply vs demand focus and ROI equations
quotes.text: So what I mean by this is if you're acquiring a new customer, you need to include the CAC of acquiring that customer, but also the CAC of acquiring the supply for that customer to purchase, which is based on some ratio between the two.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Concrete methodology for “true CAC” in marketplaces: allocate the other side’s acquisition cost using a supply-demand ratio.

quotes.topic_title: Supply vs demand focus and ROI equations
quotes.text: So basically, do I need one driver for every 10 passengers? We then take the CAC of that passenger times 10% of a driver. That gives you CAC and then you compare that to the LTV of the customer, and that allows you to calculate payback period.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: Specific example of how to compute payback by loading cross-side CAC into a single ROI equation.

quotes.topic_title: Transition: what’s different about marketplaces
quotes.text: But I find that oftentimes it's simpler just to think of a marketplace like 90 something percent of your success is going to be the same things that any business will have to deal with, growth and profit and retention, all these things.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A grounding heuristic that prevents early marketplace teams from over-indexing on marketplace theory at the expense of core business fundamentals.

quotes.topic_title: Transition: what’s different about marketplaces
quotes.text: And then there's these additional layers that make a marketplace more complicated.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A simple mental model: marketplaces are mostly like other businesses, plus extra complexity layers that must be explicitly managed.

quotes.topic_title: Transition: what’s different about marketplaces
quotes.text: So I think that effectively every decision you make in a marketplace has a second order consequence that you need to think through and maybe third and fourth order consequences at that.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A practical decision-making framework for marketplaces: evaluate second-, third-, and fourth-order effects before shipping changes.

quotes.topic_title: Transition: what’s different about marketplaces
quotes.text: Take something like pricing. It's like this is a pretty complicated topic no matter what, but if you're looking at a SaaS business and you're trying to figure out how to price your subscription, theoretically you can draw a curve which says, "As my price goes up, fewer are going to convert," and so just find the optimal point on that curve where we're managing the tangent between more customers versus more revenue per customer.
quotes.speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
quotes.context: A concrete pricing methodology (conversion vs. price curve optimization) that highlights how marketplaces add complexity beyond standard SaaS pricing logic.
